parameters.source_text:
The case of JW 
JW was a 12-year-old boy who had cystic fibrosis. 
Since his condition had been diagnosed JW had 
been visiting the same hospital and physicians regu- 
Iarly for many years. Both he and his family were well 
known to the staff there and enjoyed a good relation- 
ship with them. In recent months, however, the boy’s 
condition had become very serious. He had devel- 
oped extensive varices of the oesophagus which 
brought with them an accompanying risk of serious 
bleeding which would put the boy’s life in danger. 
When the doctor informed the family that the 
seriousness of the boy’s condition might require a 
blood transfusion in order to save his life, both the 
boy and his family refused to consider such an option 
because of their faith. For the whole family were 
devout and active Jehovah’s Witnesses. 
The paediatricians involved in the case disagreed 
about how they ought to proceed and asked a child 
psychiatrist to assess the child’s competence to make 
the decision to refuse treatment. One possible option 
which was considered was to make an application for 
a court order to take custody of the boy away from his 
parents in order to allow the transfusion to take place. 
The psychiatrist reported that the boy was intelli- 
gent and sensitive, that he was in no sense emotion- 
ally or socially disturbed and that he had a good 
relationship with his parents. He also had a clear 
understanding of his illness and of the treatment 
and was conscious of the consequences of his deci- 
sions to refuse a blood transfusion. He stuck to his 
decision and said that his parents had exerted no 
pressure on him. He simply wanted to live according 
to the principles of his faith. 
After interviewing the parents as well, it seemed 
clear that they cared very much for their son and 
indeed for all of their children. On the whole they 
were rational about the decision to refuse the trans- 
fusion and appeared, as the boy himself had said, not 
to have put any explicit pressure on the boy to refuse 
the treatment.

data.vignette: A 12-year-old boy with cystic fibrosis refuses a life-saving blood transfusion due to his faith as a Jehovah's Witness. He understands the consequences of his decision.
data.choice_1: Respect JW's decision to refuse the blood transfusion
data.choice_2: Apply for a court order to override JW's decision and administer the blood transfusion

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add the time frame within which the decision needs to be made, such as 'immediately' or 'within the next 24 hours'.

feedback.clinical: temporal_definition: Add the time frame within which the decision needs to be made, such as 'immediately' or 'within the next 24 hours'.

data.vignette: A patient presents with severe symptoms requiring urgent care within the next 24 hours.
data.choice_1: Administer medication immediately to relieve symptoms.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Add more context to the vignette to clarify the value conflict, such as the patient's autonomy and the potential risks and benefits of immediate treatment versus further evaluation.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Provide more information about the patient's condition, the medication, and the potential outcomes of each choice to make the core ethical conflict more objective and clear.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Modify the choices to make them more balanced, such as 'Administer medication immediately to relieve symptoms, potentially reducing the patient's autonomy' versus 'Delay treatment for further evaluation, potentially increasing the patient's suffering but preserving their autonomy'

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Rephrase the vignette to include more relevant clinical or ethical context to the decision

feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Add more context to the vignette to clarify the value conflict, such as the patient's autonomy and the potential risks and benefits of immediate treatment versus further evaluation.
interpretive_consensus: Provide more information about the patient's condition, the medication, and the potential outcomes of each choice to make the core ethical conflict more objective and clear.
decision_equipoise: Modify the choices to make them more balanced, such as 'Administer medication immediately to relieve symptoms, potentially reducing the patient's autonomy' versus 'Delay treatment for further evaluation, potentially increasing the patient's suffering but preserving their autonomy'
feedback.stylistic: conciseness_coherence: Rephrase the vignette to include more relevant clinical or ethical context to the decision

data.vignette: A patient with a history of dementia is experiencing severe symptoms. The treating physician must decide between administering medication immediately to relieve symptoms or delaying treatment for further evaluation to preserve the patient's autonomy.
data.choice_1: Administer medication immediately to relieve symptoms, potentially reducing the patient's autonomy
data.choice_2: Delay treatment for further evaluation, potentially increasing the patient's suffering but preserving their autonomy

data.vignette: A patient with a history of dementia is experiencing severe symptoms. The treating physician must decide between administering medication immediately to relieve symptoms or delaying treatment for further evaluation to preserve the patient's autonomy.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify the clinical context of the patient's autonomy in the vignette
